title: 107_s1868
content: The Act is titled the "National Child Protection and Volunteers for Children Improvement Act of 2002." It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. Section 5 of the National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to define the term 'qualified State program' as the policies and procedures required to implement the Act, including timely national criminal history background checks and limiting fees for State background checks. The National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to designate authorized agencies for receiving national criminal history background check requests and qualified entities for submitting these requests. The term 'routinely' is defined as instances where a high percentage of background check requests are returned within specific timeframes. SEC. 3. STRENGTHENING AND ENFORCING THE NATIONAL CHILD PROTECTION ACT AND THE VOLUNTEERS FOR CHILDREN ACT. Section 3 of the National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to include guidelines for state programs and qualifications for individuals convicted of crimes or under pending arrest. The National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to include guidelines for state programs and qualifications for individuals convicted of crimes or under pending arrest. The amendment also requires the Attorney General to respond to state authorized agencies within 15 business days regarding inquiries. The amendment also requires the Attorney General to respond to state authorized agencies within 15 business days regarding inquiries. A qualified entity in a State without a qualified program may request a national criminal background check from the Attorney General. The Attorney General must respond to requests from qualified entities within 20 business days for criminal background checks. Amendments allow state authorized agencies to disseminate criminal history records directly to qualified entities. The Attorney General must respond to requests from qualified entities within 20 business days for criminal background checks. Amendments allow state authorized agencies to disseminate criminal history records directly to qualified entities, and by striking "pursuant to subsection (a)(3)". The National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to allow the Attorney General and state agencies to share criminal history information with qualified entities. Additionally, an office for volunteer and provider screening is established. The Attorney General will establish an Office for Volunteer and Provider Screening to facilitate national criminal background checks for care providers. The Office will provide guidelines for making fitness determinations based on criminal history records. SEC. 5. FEES. Amends the National Child Protection Act to limit fees for national criminal fingerprint background checks to $5 for volunteers and $18 for providers. SEC. 6. STRENGTHENING STATE FINGERPRINT TECHNOLOGY. The Attorney General will establish a model program in each State to improve fingerprinting technology by providing funds for Live-Scan technology or electric fingerprint imaging machines. Additional funds will be provided to hire personnel for information and training in each county. The Attorney General will establish a model program in each State to improve fingerprinting technology by providing funds for Live-Scan technology or electric fingerprint imaging machines. States with a qualified program can receive up to $2,000,000 for hiring personnel to provide information and training on inputting criminal data into the national background check system. Appropriations are authorized to improve fingerprint technology units and hire data entry personnel in each State and the District of Columbia for fiscal years 2004 through 2008. SEC. 7. PRIVACY PROTECTIONS. Information from national criminal fingerprint background checks cannot be altered except for national security reasons. Qualified entities must assign a representative to handle information requests and delete unnecessary information for employment decisions. Any person who releases information from a national criminal fingerprint background check to unauthorized individuals may face criminal penalties, including fines up to $50,000 or imprisonment for up to 1 year. SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $100,000,000 authorized for fiscal year 2004 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2005 through 2008. Funds remain available until expended.
